descriptive_content: This record reports the Gini coefficient value range (0.4-0.5) for measuring spatial equity of green visibility distribution in Wuhan neighborhoods. The Gini coefficient is used as a descriptive measure of inequality, where values closer to 0 indicate more equal distribution and values closer to 1 indicate greater inequality. The range 0.4-0.5 indicates moderate inequality in green visibility distribution.

descriptive_content: This record describes spatiotemporal evolution patterns based on cluster analysis, showing cluster migration in perceived dimensions of the urban visual environment. Specifically, over time, samples shift from clusters with higher perceived quality (Cluster 2, 3, 4) to a cluster with declining perceived quality (Cluster 1). This is a descriptive finding about patterns of change in GVI and the urban perceived environment, rather than a quantified correlation or causal effect analysis. Fig. 13 visualizes the spatiotemporal distribution of clusters.

This is a comparative descriptive analysis of GVI distribution across road configurations, not a correlation or regression analysis.
